question_details.title: Will the temperature reach 90 degrees F in Jacksonville FL after the launch of this question and before April 1, 2025?
question_details.description: An introduction to the National Weather Service's Automated Surface Observing System can be found [here](https://www.weather.gov/asos/).
question_details.resolution_criteria: This question resolves as **Yes** if the high temperature in Jacksonville FL (specifically Jacksonville International Airport), as presented by [Iowa Environmental Mesonet](https://mesonet.agron.iastate.edu/sites/hist.phtml?station=JAX&network=FL_ASOS), has a high of greater than or equal to 90 degrees Fahrenheit for any day after the launch of this question and before April 1, 2025.

news:
Here are the relevant news articles:

**Mostly sunny and dry across South Florida**
South Florida is expected to be mostly sunny and dry on Wednesday, with temperatures in the upper 50s and low 60s in the morning. A brush fire in southern Miami-Dade has forced the closure of Card Sound Road, and the wind will play a role in determining where the smoke will move. Rain is not expected to help with the containment of the fire, and it will be mainly dry and sunny in the afternoon with highs in the low 80s. There is a moderate risk of rip currents along the Atlantic beaches. Thursday will be the warmest day of the week, with highs in the mid 80s, but it will be breezy. The weekend will be warmer, with highs in the low 80s, and early next week the chance of rain increases with spotty showers on Monday and scattered showers on Tuesday.
Original language: en
Publish date: March 19, 2025 12:21 PM
Source:[CBS News](https://www.cbsnews.com/miami/news/mostly-sunny-and-dry-across-south-florida/)

**Vilfand Predicts Up to 14 Degrees Celsius in Moscow Next Week**
Roman Vilfand, the scientific director of the Russian Hydrometeorological Center, has predicted that the temperature in Moscow may reach up to 14 degrees Celsius next week. 'The temperature will be above 10 degrees Celsius on March 23 and 24, with daytime temperatures ranging from +6 to +11 degrees Celsius. It will be sunny due to high pressure, and the air masses will be moving from the south,' Vilfand said. He added that on March 25, daytime temperatures are expected to range from +9 to +14 degrees Celsius, with mostly clear skies and little precipitation. 'There will be plenty of sunshine in the coming days, and if you stand outside for an hour, you might even get a sunburn,' Vilfand concluded. This comes after Tatyana Pozdnyakova, the chief specialist at the Moscow Meteorological Bureau, predicted that April will be 3 degrees warmer than normal in Moscow. Vilfand also previously stated that spring 2025 temperatures will be within or slightly below normal, and that the winter of 2024-2025 was the second warmest on record.
Original language: ru
Publish date: March 19, 2025 12:15 PM
Source:[Izvestia.ru](https://iz.ru/1856652/2025-03-19/vilfand-sprognoziroval-do-14-gradusov-tepla-v-moskve-na-sleduiushchei-nedele)

**Russia's April Weather Forecast: Warmer Than Usual**
According to a forecast by Moscow's meteorological office, temperatures in the Central Federal District (CFO) are expected to be three degrees warmer than usual. As meteorologist Tatyana Pozdnyakova said, 'This means that the average monthly air temperature will exceed 10 degrees Celsius. April 2025 will have a similar air temperature to April 2024.' 
Original language: ru
Publish date: March 19, 2025 07:26 AM
Source:[RZN.info](https://www.rzn.info/news/2025/3/19/rossiyanam-dali-prognoz-aprelskoj-pogody-v-cfo-313899.html)

**April in Moscow to be Abnormally Warm, Says Meteorologist Tatyana Podynyakova**
According to meteorologist Tatyana Podynyakova, April in Moscow will be abnormally warm, with a mean monthly temperature above +10°C. 'All seasonal weather forecast models are unanimous in their calculations: a positive temperature anomaly will persist in April, averaging around +3°C. This means that the mean monthly temperature will exceed +10°C,' she wrote in her Telegram channel. Podynyakova notes that April this year will be similar to April 2024 in terms of temperature. However, the forecast for precipitation is uncertain, with both a deficit and an excess being equally likely. Last year, April saw an excess of precipitation, with 37 mm of normal precipitation exceeded by 130-150%.
Original language: ru
Publish date: March 19, 2025 06:20 AM
Source:[Российская газета](https://rg.ru/2025/03/19/reg-cfo/sinoptik-pozdniakova-v-aprele-anomalno-teplaia-pogoda-v-moskve-sohranitsia.html)

**Dante Ricci: Cold returns after taste of spring**
Putnam County can expect a cold return after a taste of spring, with gusty north winds and chances of snow showers on Thursday. The cooler pattern will continue on Friday with abundant sunshine and breezy west winds. Temperatures will struggle to reach the 50s, and a light jacket will still be needed for the weekend. Rain chances return on Saturday, with highs in the 60s ahead of a cold front. The long-range pattern signals a return to colder air and below-normal temperatures in April, with a rollercoaster effect continuing in the region.
Original language: en
Publish date: March 19, 2025 04:00 AM
Source:[The Herald-Dispatch](https://www.herald-dispatch.com/news/putnam_news/dante-ricci-cold-returns-after-taste-of-spring/article_c9346e78-029a-11f0-9364-d73a8b4c5c6a.html)

**Possible First Summer Day of 2025: Temperatures to Reach Up to 25 Degrees Celsius**
A meteorologist, Dominik Jung, predicts that it could be the first summer day of the year 2025 on Friday, with temperatures reaching up to 25 degrees Celsius. According to the German Weather Service (DWD), a summer day is defined as a day with a minimum air temperature of 25 degrees Celsius. Jung says that it will be unusually warm for the season, with temperatures in the west and southwest reaching up to 20 degrees Celsius, and locally even warmer. In the east, temperatures will reach up to 21 degrees Celsius, and in the north, up to 18 degrees Celsius. Jung also notes that the sun will shine brightly throughout the country, with 10-12 hours of sunshine per day. However, a high-pressure system called 'Konstantina' will bring Saharan dust to the country, which may cloud the sky in the west on Friday. Despite this, temperatures are expected to remain warm over the weekend, with values of 15-22 degrees Celsius predicted for Saturday and Sunday. Jung notes that it is still unclear how the weather will develop in April and May, and that cold air masses may still occur.
Original language: de
Publish date: March 18, 2025 02:14 PM
Source:[T-online.de](https://www.t-online.de/nachrichten/panorama/wetter/id_100641434/wetter-bis-zu-25-grad-diese-woche-erster-sommertag-moeglich.html)

**Tomsk to Experience a Short Warmth Before a Cold Snap**
According to Gismeteo, Tomsk can expect temperatures to rise to +10 degrees Celsius on March 19-20, 2025, with the air warming up to 16:00. The next two days are expected to be sunny, but a small rain is forecasted for the night of March 18-19. However, a cold snap is predicted for March 25-26, with temperatures potentially dropping to -3 degrees Celsius during the day and -6 to -9 degrees Celsius at night. Temperatures around 0 degrees Celsius are also forecasted for March 22, 27, and 28. 'No warm weather is expected in Tomsk until April 20, 2025,' according to the preliminary forecast.
Original language: ru
Publish date: March 18, 2025 07:15 AM
Source:[Аргументы и факты](https://tomsk.aif.ru/society/poteplenie-do-10-gradusov-ozhidaetsya-v-tomske-19-20-marta)

**Unseasonable Heat Wave to Hit Leningrad Region in April**
A synoptician has predicted that April 2025 in the Leningrad region will bring an unusual heat wave, with daytime temperatures reaching +20 degrees Celsius from the beginning of the month and potentially exceeding +25 degrees Celsius by the second half of the month. This will lead to an early awakening of nature and infrastructure in the region. While the early warmth brings pleasant prospects, it may also have negative consequences, such as early tree blooming, which can cause problems for people with allergies, and an increase in forest fires due to dry soil. However, for gardeners, this will be a welcome gift, as the long-awaited dacha season will start much earlier. For people with weather-related health issues, the rapid temperature fluctuations may pose a significant challenge. As a result, it is essential to be prepared for the unusual consequences of this early summer. This spring once again highlights the global climate changes that have affected even our familiar weather patterns.
Original language: ru
Publish date: March 17, 2025 05:31 PM
Source:[ngzt.ru](https://ngzt.ru/news/anomalnaya-zhara-nagryanet-v-aprele-leto-nastupit-na-dva-mesyaca-ranshe-rasskazal-sinoptik/)

**FIRST ALERT WEATHER: Beautiful St. Patrick’s Day 🍀**
This St. Patrick's Day in Jacksonville, Florida, is expected to be beautiful with full sunshine and highs in the 60s. Temperatures will drop into the 50s this morning but will warm up to near 80 by Wednesday. Spring begins on Thursday with the spring equinox at 5:01 a.m. First Alert Meteorologist Trevor Gibbs has a 7-day forecast available, which includes a chance of showers on Thursday. 'It's going to be a great day,' said Gibbs, but 'warming up to near 80 by Wednesday ahead of a few showers Thursday.'
Original language: en
Publish date: March 17, 2025 08:35 AM
Source:[actionnewsjax.com](https://www.actionnewsjax.com/news/local/first-alert-weather-beautiful-st-patricks-day/AAINBO4LARA2HINQIJCI3TQBNU/)

**Mayor Deegan Shares Updates on 904 Lean & Announces Additional COJ Efficiency Initiatives - Free Press of Jacksonville**
Jacksonville Mayor Deegan shared updates on the 904 LEAN initiative, which has streamlined the permitting process, digitized contract approvals, and automated expense reports, among other improvements. The City has also certified 34 LEAN Green Belts, saving each employee an average of 800 hours, and has an additional 67 Green Belts on track for certification. These efforts have saved the City over 216,000 hours of employee time, equivalent to a year's worth of work for 103 employees. Mayor Deegan also announced that Jacksonville is partnering with C3 AI to leverage AI and advanced financial modeling to improve its budgeting process, and is working on new legislation to ensure fairness and accountability for taxpayer dollars.
Original language: en
Publish date: March 14, 2025 06:54 PM
Source:[jacksonvillefreepress.com](https://jacksonvillefreepress.com/mayor-deegan-shares-updates-on-904-lean-announces-additional-coj-efficiency-initiatives/)

**FIRST ALERT WEATHER: Cool day before a February freeze arrives**
A cool day is expected in Jacksonville, Florida, with temperatures in the 40s and lower 50s. Highs will only reach the mid to upper 50s, with winds picking up in the afternoon. Tonight, widespread inland frost and freeze are expected near and west of Jacksonville, with temperatures dipping to the upper 20s in some neighborhoods in Georgia. The beaches of Jacksonville will stay just above freezing due to onshore winds. Temperatures will warm up to the 60s on Saturday and Sunday. According to the forecast, 'Today will feature mostly cloudy skies and temperatures in the 40s and lower 50s.' 'Highs today will only be in the mid to upper 50s.' 'Widespread inland frost/freeze tonight near and west of Jacksonville and all of SE Georgia.' 'Temperatures will dip to the upper 20s in some neighborhoods in Georgia.'
Original language: en
Publish date: February 20, 2025 12:30 PM
Source:[wokv.com](https://www.wokv.com/news/local/first-alert-weather-cool-day-before-february-freeze-arrives/6TMAELOKBRD2DPSYXDVZ3GRQGY/)

**A dry day with rain on the way later this week**
Good morning, Jacksonville! Temperatures will start in the 40s and 50s this morning, reaching highs in the upper 50s and low 60s by this afternoon. A Frost Advisory is in effect until 8am. A system will move through, bringing a 30% chance of rain on Tuesday night, increasing to a 90% chance of rain on Wednesday. After Wednesday, sunshine is expected to return.
Original language: en
Publish date: February 17, 2025 09:59 AM
Source:[news4jax.com](https://www.news4jax.com/weather/2025/02/17/a-dry-day-with-rain-on-the-way-later-this-week/)

**FIRST ALERT WEATHER: Chilly mornings to start the week, Tracking midweek rain**
This week in Jacksonville, Florida, will start with chilly mornings, with temperatures in the 40s and 50s. Highs will be in the upper 50s to lower 60s today, but will rise to near 70 degrees tomorrow afternoon. However, Wednesday will be soggy with rain, and highs will only be in the upper 50s by Thursday. Inland areas can expect a freeze by Friday morning. Tonight will be mostly clear and chilly, with patchy inland frost. Tuesday will be mostly sunny, with highs in the upper 60s. Wednesday will be cloudy with rain, and Thursday will be mostly sunny and cool.
Original language: en
Publish date: February 17, 2025 09:38 AM
Source:[wokv.com](https://www.wokv.com/news/local/first-alert-weather-chilly-mornings-start-week-tracking-midweek-rain/G5VKZGUR7NETBMN3NRJTZ6P3UE/)

**Weather Forecast for Jacksonville, Florida on February 7th**
The National Weather Service (NWS) has released the weather forecast for Jacksonville, Florida for today, February 7th. The temperatures are expected to range from a high of 27°C to a low of 16°C. According to the NWS, the climate in the eastern United States is generally humid and subtropical, with abundant rainfall and mild winters. In contrast, the southwestern United States has a dry climate with hot summers and scarce rainfall. The NWS also notes that the start of summer and the beginning of winter in the United States are determined by the astronomical calendar, with the summer ending on the autumnal equinox (usually between September 22nd and 23rd) and the winter beginning on the winter solstice (usually between December 21st and 22nd).
Original language: es
Publish date: February 07, 2025 11:20 AM
Source:[larepublica.pe](https://larepublica.pe/estados-unidos/2025/02/07/clima-de-hoy-en-florida-pronostico-del-tiempo-en-jacksonville-este-7-de-febrero-segun-national-weather-service-pronostico-del-tiempo-de-manana-lrtmusc-407647)

**First Alert Weather: Near record warm temperatures this weekend**
The First Alert Weather Team is predicting record or near-record warm temperatures in Jacksonville, Florida, from Thursday to Sunday, with temperatures reaching the 80s each day. The warm temperatures will extend to the beaches due to offshore winds. The weather will be mostly dry, with only small chances of showers early next week and rising pollen counts. Tonight, skies will be partly cloudy with some areas of fog, with a low of 56.
Original language: en
Publish date: February 05, 2025 09:21 PM
Source:[actionnewsjax.com](https://www.actionnewsjax.com/news/local/first-alert-weather-near-record-warm-temperatures-this-weekend/FC6IUWLVNZAYXG5P4MQ26RZNVM/)

**First Alert Weather: Beautiful and dry weekend ahead**
The First Alert Weather team is forecasting a dry and beautiful weekend in Jacksonville, Florida, with no rain in sight. A cold front passed through the area overnight, bringing temperatures down to the 50s. The rest of the weekend will be dry, with a mix of sun and clouds bringing temperatures inland to the 70s. Next week, highs are expected to approach 80 degrees with no rain, but pollen is expected to surge during this time.
Original language: en
Publish date: February 01, 2025 02:39 PM
Source:[wokv.com](https://www.wokv.com/news/local/first-alert-weather-beautiful-dry-weekend-ahead/UXNBQXJTBFBERBJKESFL7YOQTE/)

**FIRST ALERT WEATHER: Warmest temps in months and a weak weekend cold front**
A cool start to Friday morning in Jacksonville, Florida, will give way to warm temperatures, reaching the 80s for the first time in two months. A weak cold front will bring a few showers tonight, with low rain amounts expected. The rain will clear by sunrise tomorrow, and the weekend will be dry, with temperatures gradually warming up again through the week. The long-term weather pattern is expected to be dry, which may lead to increased pollen and wildfire risks as we approach the start of pollen/wildfire season.
Original language: en
Publish date: January 31, 2025 11:29 AM
Source:[wokv.com](https://www.wokv.com/news/local/first-alert-weather-warmest-temps-months-weak-weekend-cold-front/GVSMCOLVBVH6LEP6BJ7G2YN5NM/)

**FIRST ALERT WEATHER| Beautiful weather ahead**
This week in Jacksonville, Florida, expect pleasant weather with high temperatures near 70 degrees. Thursday will be similar but a tad cooler along the beach communities. By Friday, temperatures will be much warmer. A few showers are likely early Saturday, but the remainder of the weekend will be dry and nice. Tonight will be clear and cool with a low of 47 degrees.
Original language: en
Publish date: January 29, 2025 11:31 AM
Source:[actionnewsjax.com](https://www.actionnewsjax.com/news/local/first-alert-weather-beautiful-weather-ahead/WKHIOCWEEVCPTLJTYMYVMWUJWY/)

**First Alert Weather: The warming trend is underway**
The First Alert Weather Team reports that temperatures are rising in Jacksonville, Florida. Expect partly to mostly cloudy skies with lows in the 40s to low 50s tonight. The rest of the week will be partly cloudy with temperatures near or above average, with no threat of frost or freezes through the next 7 days. High temperatures will peak at 80 degrees on Friday. A weak front on Friday night will bring a few showers into early Saturday morning, but temperatures will only be slightly cooler. According to the 7-day forecast, temperatures will range from 41 to 70 degrees throughout the week.
Original language: en
Publish date: January 27, 2025 09:03 PM
Source:[wokv.com](https://www.wokv.com/news/local/first-alert-weather-warming-trend-is-underway/4S25TD4OPJAV3LC3LHJHOJRFYA/)

**First Alert Weather: One more freeze before a much-needed warming trend**
The First Alert Weather team is forecasting one more freeze before a warming trend over the next week. Saturday morning was the coldest morning of the winter so far, with temperatures at Jacksonville International Airport (JIA) dropping to 26 degrees. However, temperatures will steadily warm up throughout the week, with morning temperatures reaching the 40s and 50s and daytime highs reaching the 70s by Wednesday. According to the forecast, 'we aren't going to freeze' on Monday morning, and temperatures will continue to warm up into the weekend.
Original language: en
Publish date: January 26, 2025 02:01 AM
Source:[wokv.com](https://www.wokv.com/news/local/first-alert-weather-one-more-freeze-before-much-needed-warming-trend/TNWHWEUNOJBK3OSKME2ILQBN3U/)

**Weather Whiplash: Jacksonville to see temperatures in the 80s after deep freeze**
Jacksonville, Florida is expected to experience a significant warm-up after a prolonged period of cold weather. According to weather models, a pattern reversal is predicted to occur next week, replacing arctic air with milder breezes and pushing temperatures into the 70s. By February, temperatures are expected to reach the 80s, marking an early end to Winter. This shift is attributed to the Negative North Atlantic Oscillation (NAO) and Arctic Oscillation (AO) weather patterns, which are expected to transition to the Positive Phase. As a result, residents are advised to keep their winter coats handy for a few more days, but to be prepared to trade them in for shorts as Spring weather approaches.
Original language: en
Publish date: January 24, 2025 04:35 PM
Source:[news4jax.com](https://www.news4jax.com/weather/2025/01/24/weather-whiplash-jacksonville-to-see-temperatures-in-the-80s-after-deep-freeze/)

**Plenty of sunshine on an otherwise chilly day**
A sunny day is expected in Jacksonville, Florida, with temperatures potentially reaching 50 degrees. However, it's still significantly below normal and a Freeze Watch is in effect for all counties from 9 p.m. Friday night through Saturday morning, with sub-freezing temperatures as low as 22 possible. Residents are advised to continue covering sensitive vegetation, taking care of pets, pipes, and checking on people to ensure they are fully insulated.
Original language: en
Publish date: January 24, 2025 04:08 PM
Source:[news4jax.com](https://www.news4jax.com/weather/2025/01/24/prepare-for-the-cold-to-stick-around-for-the-last-weekend-of-january/)

**FIRST ALERT WEATHER: Cold mornings continue, gradual warming trend in view**
Bitter cold continues in Jacksonville, Florida, with temperatures in the 20s inland and 30s closer to the coast. However, a gradual warming trend is expected, with highs reaching the lower 50s tomorrow and upper 50s by Sunday. Tonight will be partly cloudy and cold, with widespread frost and freeze. Morning frost and freeze are also expected on Saturday and Sunday. According to the forecast, today will be partly sunny and cold, with a high of 49. 'It's going to be a cold morning, but we're looking at a gradual warming trend over the next few days,' said the weather forecast. 'We'll see highs in the 50s by Sunday, so that's a nice change of pace.'
Original language: en
Publish date: January 24, 2025 10:52 AM
Source:[wokv.com](https://www.wokv.com/news/local/first-alert-weather-cold-mornings-continue-gradual-warming-trend-view/GWZDFQRKA5E4NDN25HXGW6QD6I/)

phase_1_result.initial_reasoning: Based on historical climate data for Jacksonville, FL, during the month of March, the temperature can sometimes reach 90°F but it is relatively infrequent. Typically, March highs in Jacksonville range from the mid-70s to the low 80s, with occasional peaks into the upper 80s. Historical climate records show that reaching 90°F is uncommon but not unprecedented. An initial estimate would place the probability around 20%, based on the historical potential for a very warm day as March transitions to April.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Current Weather Patterns
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: As an expert in short-term weather forecasting, I can consider prevailing weather patterns such as fronts, high-pressure systems, or heatwaves that are currently impacting the region or are forecasted to develop over the next two weeks. If there is a high-pressure system or record warmth progressing from other parts of the Southeast, this could lead to higher than average temperatures in Jacksonville.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Local Microclimate Effects
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: Jacksonville is subject to the microclimate effects of its proximity to the Atlantic Ocean, which can moderate temperatures. This dampens the probability of reaching a sustained high of 90°F unless offshore conditions are significantly warm or atmospheric conditions allow for onshore warming.

analysis_updates.points_reinforcing_prior_analysis: The current weather forecast for Jacksonville, Florida indicates a warming trend with temperatures potentially approaching 80°F as seen in articles indicating highs reaching the 80s for the upcoming days, especially as the weather warms up towards the weekend. The warmer weather pattern supports the earlier assessment of a possibility of hitting 90°F.
analysis_updates.points_challenging_prior_analysis: Despite the warming trend, there is no direct forecast data predicting a surge to 90°F specifically. The nearby South Florida forecast indicates temperatures in the mid-80s, suggesting warm conditions but not necessarily hitting the 90°F threshold.

phase_1_result.initial_reasoning: Based on historical weather data for Jacksonville, Florida, the probability of reaching 90 degrees Fahrenheit in March is relatively low, although not impossible. According to historical climate records, reaching or exceeding 90 degrees in March occurs infrequently, typically in the latter part of the month. Generally, temperatures start rising significantly in April. Thus, the base rate derived from historical conditions for March is around 10%.

perspective_derived_factors.name: El Niño Conditions
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: Current atmospheric patterns indicate a moderate El Niño event, which can lead to warmer-than-usual temperatures in the southeastern United States. El Niño tends to elevate winter and early spring temperatures, increasing the likelihood of daily highs reaching extreme values for the season.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Current Weather Trends
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: Recent weather forecasts and trends for the region show a warming pattern with higher-than-normal temperatures over the next two weeks. This ongoing trend supports the possibility of daily highs approaching the 90-degree mark.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Historical Late-March Temperatures
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: While uncommon, there have been instances where late March temperatures in Jacksonville reached or exceeded 90 degrees Fahrenheit, typically being driven by specific atmospheric conditions such as strong high-pressure systems.

analysis_updates.points_reinforcing_prior_analysis: The news indicates a possibility of upcoming warm weather patterns in the region, with some articles highlighting warmer days in the 80s expected later in the week, especially on Thursday and the weekend. Additionally, the mention of minimal rain and plenty of sunshine further supports the likelihood of warmer conditions approaching. The consistent mention of a warming trend aligns with the previous analysis suggesting warmer-than-average temperatures due to climatic factors such as El Niño.
analysis_updates.points_challenging_prior_analysis: There are no significant points in the news that strongly challenge the prior analysis. The overall weather trends appear to support the forecast of warmer days, with specific mention of high temperatures reaching the 80s.

phase_1_result.initial_reasoning: Jacksonville, FL, commonly experiences temperatures of 90 degrees Fahrenheit starting in late spring, but it is less frequent in March. Typically, the historical data from the National Weather Service and the Iowa Environmental Mesonet suggest that the probability is lower in March. Based on historical climate data for Jacksonville, the frequency of hitting temperatures of 90 degrees F this early in the year is relatively low, roughly around 15%.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Current Weather Patterns
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: Assessing current weather patterns over the southeastern United States can provide insights into potential temperature fluctuations. If a strong warm front is moving through the area and high-pressure systems are expected to linger, this can increase the probability of higher temperatures.

perspective_derived_factors.name: El Niño Impact
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: An active El Niño period typically causes more storms but can also lead to warmer-than-average temperatures in some parts of Florida during winter and early spring.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Local Microclimate Variability
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: Microclimates can cause local temperature variations. The urban heat island effect, where urban areas tend to be warmer, could slightly elevate temperatures but wouldn’t typically raise March temps by enough to hit 90 degrees.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Proximity to Water Bodies
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: Jacksonville's proximity to significant water bodies can moderate extreme temperatures, typically leading to cooler conditions during early spring.

analysis_updates.points_reinforcing_prior_analysis: The news articles indicate a warming trend in Jacksonville, with temperatures expected to reach near 80 degrees by Wednesday. This supports the likelihood of a warm weather pattern increasing temperatures as it aligns with an observed trend toward reaching the 80s.
analysis_updates.points_challenging_prior_analysis: However, despite the warming trend, temperatures in Jacksonville are still projected to be around the low to mid-80s at their peak in the upcoming week. There is no direct mention of temperatures reaching 90 degrees before April 1st.

phase_1_result.initial_reasoning: Historically, temperatures in Jacksonville, FL reach 90 degrees Fahrenheit predominantly in the summer months. March is typically cooler, with average highs around 75-80 degrees Fahrenheit. The historical base rate for March reaching 90 degrees in Jacksonville is low. Reviewing historical weather data for March, there are very few instances of temperatures reaching or exceeding 90°F before April 1st.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Climate Change
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: Long-term climate change is associated with increasing average temperatures and more frequent temperature extremes. This increases the probability of experiencing unusually high temperatures even during typically cooler months like March.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Current Weather Patterns
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: Weather patterns, such as high-pressure systems, can lead to unseasonably warm temperatures. If current weather patterns indicate such systems over Jacksonville, this could raise the probability. However, without specific current observations on a heatwave or similar phenomena in this period, such an adjustment is not warranted.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Urban Heat Island Effect
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: Urban areas often experience higher temperatures than their surroundings due to human activities and infrastructure that retain heat. Jacksonville's airport may be affected by this, but this would only slightly increase overall temperature readings.

perspective_derived_factors.name: El Niño/La Niña Influence
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: These ocean-atmosphere phenomena significantly affect weather patterns. If there is an ongoing El Niño, it could result in warmer-than-average temperatures for the area, but accounting for specific data regarding its intensity or presence is necessary. In its absence, no adjustment is made.

analysis_updates.points_reinforcing_prior_analysis: None of the articles provide evidence of temperatures in Jacksonville, FL reaching the 90 degrees Fahrenheit mark. Instead, they mention highs in the upper 50s, 60s, and approaching 80 degrees. Additionally, the articles highlight breezy conditions and chances of showers, which do not contribute to extreme heat.
analysis_updates.points_challenging_prior_analysis: The news articles indicate cooler temperatures, with no mention of extreme heat events occurring in Jacksonville, FL. Reports emphasize cooler mornings and temperatures slowly warming to the 80s, but not reaching 90 degrees Fahrenheit. The absence of any indication of a heatwave or unusually high temperature surge in March is a challenge to the initial analysis.

phase_1_result.initial_reasoning: Based on historical temperature data for Jacksonville, Florida, the likelihood of temperatures reaching or exceeding 90 degrees Fahrenheit in March is relatively low. Historical records show that the average high temperature for March is generally in the 70s (F), with occasional spikes into the 80s (F) but rarely reaching 90 degrees (F). Looking at climate data over the past decade, temperatures reaching 90 degrees Fahrenheit in Jacksonville during March is uncommon, happening only in about 5-10% of Marches. Therefore, I will set an initial probability of 10%, based on historical records of similar weather patterns in March.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Recent Climate Trends
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: Recent trends in climate data have shown an increase in extreme weather occurrences and a gradual rise in temperatures globally, which can increase the chances of experiencing atypically high temperatures for a season. This trend in climate change increases the probability of higher temperatures in March in Florida than historically observed.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Urban Heat Island Effect

Initial probabilities ranged from 10% to 40%, with considerations of historical climate data, climate change effects, current weather patterns, and other factors influencing their assessments. In phase 2, experts adjusted their probabilities slightly, with most increasing or maintaining their estimates due to ongoing warming trends, though still noting the absence of direct forecasts predicting 90°F temperatures. Revised probabilities after phase 2 ranged from 10% to 40%, reflecting a cautious expectation of warming but no definitive prediction of reaching 90°F before the specified date.
